Description: THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO FUND THE STATE’S WORK IN SUPPORT OF THE PESTICIDE DATA PROGRAM (PDP).  THE STATE WILL COLLECT FOOD SAMPLES IN THEIR STATE AND SHIP THE SAMPLES TO THE ASSIGNED LABORATORIES PER THE ESTABLISHED SCHEDULE.  THE FOODS, WHICH FOCUS ON THOSE MOST FREQUENTLY CONSUMED BY INFANTS AND CHILDREN, ARE SPECIFIED IN THE CURRENT PDP PROJECT PLAN THAT IS POSTED ON THE PDP WEBSITE.  THE RECEIVING STATE LABORATORY WILL PERFORM CHEMICAL ANALYSES ON THE ASSIGNED SAMPLES FOR PESTICIDE RESIDUES, INCLUDING PARENT COMPOUNDS AND METABOLITES.  THE RESULTS OF THE RESIDUE ANALYSIS WILL BE REVIEWED BY THE STATE QUALITY ASSURANCE OFFICER AND SENT TO PDP AS AN ELECTRONIC DATASET.  ALL WORK WILL BE CONDUCTED ACCORDING TO STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES THAT ARE AVAILABLE ON THE PDP WEBSITE. THE DELIVERABLE OF THE SAMPLING OPERATION IS TO PROVIDE THE REQUESTED SAMPLES TO THE LABORATORIES.  THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY, WHO USES THE DATA TO PREPAREDIETARY RISK ASSESSMENTS FOR PESTICIDES; THE FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION WHO USES THE ROUTINE MONITORING DATA FROM PDP TO INFORM THEIR REGULATORY ENFORCEMENT OF ESTABLISHED LIMITS OF PESTICIDE RESIDUES IN FOOD; THE USDA FOREIGN AGRICULTURAL SERVICE WHO MAY USE THE DATA IN TRADE NEGOTIATIONS; AND AMERICAN CONSUMERS WHO USE THE DATA TO HELP ENSURE THEIR CONFIDENCE IN THE FOOD THEY PURCHASE FOR THEIR FAMILIES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS FOR THE ORGANIC TRADE ASSOCIATION (OTA) TO PROVIDE SUPPORT TO THE NATIONAL ORGANIC PROGRAM (NOP) AND EXISTING TRANSITION TO ORGANIC PARTNERSHIP PROGRAM (TOPP) PARTNERS. OTA AND ITS SUB-AWARDEES WILL PROVIDE EXPERTISE AND WIDESPREAD INDUSTRY REACH TO BUILD PARTNERSHIPS AND FOSTER COLLABORATION WITH ORGANIZATIONS TO SUPPORT TOPP INITIATIVES. OTA ACTIVITIES WILL FOCUS ON TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE IN MARKET DEVELOPMENT AND ASSESSMENT, SUPPLY AND DEMAND DISCOVERY, AND HANDLING TRANSITION AND EDUCATION. DATA COLLECTION AND REPORTING OF THESE ACTIVITIES WILL SUBSEQUENTLY BE PRESENTED THROUGH DELIVERABLES, INCLUDING DEVELOPING KEY PERFORMANCE INDICATORS TO ASSESS PROGRESS, IMPACT, AND EFFECTIVENESS; PROJECT MANAGEMENT ROADMAP; OUTREACH AND RECRUITMENT OVERARCHING ROADMAP PLAN; QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS; RESOURCES SUCH AS VIDEOS, PRESENTATIONS, AND MATERIALS; AND VARIOUS PROJECT PLANS. THIS WORK WILL BENEFIT TRANSITIONING AND ORGANIC PRODUCERS AND HANDLERS, INCLUDING PROCESSORS, MANUFACTURERS, DISTRIBUTORS, BRANDS, AND OTHERS. AN EXPANSION OF DOMESTIC ORGANIC PRODUCERS AND HANDLERS WILL DIRECTLY IMPACT THE ORGANIC MARKET, THEREBY RESULTING IN MORE DIVERSE AND RESILIENT ORGANIC SUPPLY CHAINS. OTA WILL COLLABORATE WITH PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS, HEREAFTER SUBAWARDEES, TO COMPLETE THE SCOPE OF THE WORK OUTLINED IN THE AGREEMENT. SUBAWARDEES ARE EXPECTED TO INCLUDE RODALE INSTITUTE, ORGANIC AGRONOMY TRAINING SERVICE, ORGANIC INTEGRITY COOPERATIVE GUILD, WOLF AND ASSOCIATES, MERCARIS, BLACK FARMERS INDEX, AND NATIONAL LATINO FARMERS AND RANCHERS. OTHER SUBAWARDEES MAY BE ADDED TO ACCOMPLISH THE GOALS OF THE AGREEMENT. THE SUBAWARDS WILL SUPPORT THE PRIME AWARD THROUGH ACTIVITIES RELATED TO RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT, TECHNICAL EXPERTISE, AND OUTREACH EVENTS.

THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT IS TO CONDUCT AN ANNUAL PEER REVIEW OF THE NATIONAL ORGANIC PROGRAM’S (NOP) ADHERENCE TO ACCREDITATION PROCEDURES AS REQUIRED BY 7 CFR §205.509. THE PEER REVIEW WILL: 1) EVALUATE THE NOP’S POLICIES AND PROCEDURES FOR CONFORMANCE TO THE ORGANIC REGULATIONS AND ISO/IEC 17011:2017 - REQUIREMENTS FOR ACCREDITATION BODIES ACCREDITING CONFORMITY ASSESSMENT BODIES; AND 2) REVIEW CERTIFICATION BODY ACCREDITATION DECISIONS MADE BY THE NOP THROUGH FILE REVIEWS. THE COOPERATOR WILL CONDUCT THE DOCUMENT REVIEWS PRIOR TO CONDUCTING A VIRTUAL ONSITE ASSESSMENT WITH NOP PERSONNEL. THE COOPERATOR’S PEER REVIEW PANEL WILL GENERATE A REPORT OF THE ASSESSMENT INCLUDING OPPORTUNITIES FOR IMPROVEMENT AND OBSERVATIONS. THE NOP WILL PRESENT THE 2023 PEER REVIEW FINAL REPORT AT THE NEXT SCHEDULED NATIONAL ORGANIC STANDARDS BOARD MEETING (A FEDERAL ADVISORY COMMITTEE THAT PROVIDES RECOMMENDATIONS TO THE FEDERAL AGENCY). ADDITIONALLY, THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WILL PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE ON DEVELOPING THE NOP’S ACCREDITATION POLICIES AND PROCEDURES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS FOR THE ORGANIC MATERIALS REVIEW INSTITUTE (OMRI) TO USE THEIR EXPERTISE IN SUBSTANCE REVIEW TO AUTHOR TECHNICAL REPORTS AND OTHER SUPPORTIVE ITEMS NEEDED FOR NATIONAL ORGANIC PROGRAM (NOP) PROJECTS DIRECTLY RELATED TO THE NATIONAL LIST OF ALLOWED AND PROHIBITED SUBSTANCES (NATIONAL LIST). OMRI WILL AUTHOR UP TO FIFTEEN TECHNICAL REPORTS EACH YEAR TO SUPPORT NATIONAL ORGANIC STANDARDS BOARD SUNSET REVIEWS AND REVIEW OF PETITIONED SUBSTANCES FOR THE NATIONAL LIST. IN ADDITION, OMRI MAY BE REQUESTED TO PROVIDE RESEARCH AND REPORTING ON SUBSTANCES, CREATE CONTENT FOR PRESENTATIONS AND OUTREACH, AND PREPARE DELIVERABLES FOR THE NOP PROJECT MANAGER TO REVIEW. OMRI WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR THE ADMINISTRATION OF THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT AS DESCRIBED IN ITS PROPOSAL, INCLUDING ATTENDANCE AT REGULARLY SCHEDULED CHECK-IN MEETINGS AND PROVIDING SUPPORT TO PROJECT NEEDS. THE NOP WILL INFORM OMRI OF A PROJECT NEED, AFTER WHICH OMRI WILL RESPOND WITH A PROPOSED TIMELINE AND SET OF DELIVERABLES. THIS WORK WILL BENEFIT FARMERS, BUSINESSES, CONSUMERS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC WHO ARE DIRECTLY INVOLVED AND INTERESTED IN SUBSTANCES ALLOWED AND PROHIBITED IN ORGANIC PRODUCTION. THE DISBURSEMENT OF THIS AWARD WILL NOT INVOLVE SUBAWARDS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PROVIDE TECHNICAL SUPPORT, MENTORSHIP, ONLINE RESOURCES, EDUCATION, AND NETWORKING OPPORTUNITIES FOR TRANSITIONING AND ORGANIC FARMERS ACROSS THE UNITED STATES, INCLUDING THOSE FROM HISTORICALLY UNDERSERVED COMMUNITY GROUPS. ORGANIC FARMERS ASSOCIATION WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR THE ADMINISTRATION OF THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT, COLLABORATING WITH SUBAWARDEES, DEVELOPING RESOURCES AND TEMPLATES FOR THE ORGANIC AGRICULTURE SECTOR, AND PREPARING DOCUMENTS FOR THE NATIONAL ORGANIC PROGRAM’S PUBLICLY AVAILABLE ORGANIC INTEGRITY LEARNING CENTER. THE OVERARCHING GOAL OF THIS AWARD IS FOR THE ORGANIC FARMERS ASSOCIATION TO PROVIDE NATIONAL SUPPORT TO FARMERS AND REGIONAL LEAD PARTNERS IN THE TRANSITION TO ORGANIC PARTNERSHIP PROGRAM. DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE COMMUNICATIONS AND OUTREACH PLANS DETAILING RESOURCES SHARED WITH FARMERS, REPORTS INCLUDING KEY FINDINGS AND TAKEAWAYS, QUARTERLY PROGRESS REPORTS, PLANNING DOCUMENTS, AND PHOTO OR VIDEO JOURNALISTIC NARRATIVES. IN ADDITION TO CREATING NEW TECHNICAL DOCUMENTS AND RESOURCES, THE AWARDEE WILL PROVIDE DATA ON THE NUMBER OF FARMERS WHO RECEIVE SERVICES THROUGH THIS AWARD. THIS WORK WILL BENEFIT TRANSITIONING AND ORGANIC FARMERS BY CREATING AND SHARING RESOURCES THAT HELP ADDRESS BARRIERS TO ORGANIC CERTIFICATION AND BY ESTABLISHING NEW COMMUNITY BUILDING OPPORTUNITIES, A KEY FACTOR IN SUCCESSFUL ORGANIC TRANSITION. OFA WILL COLLABORATE WITH PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS, HEREAFTER SUBAWARDEES, TO COMPLETE THE SCOPE OF THE WORK OUTLINED IN THE AGREEMENT. SUBAWARDEES WILL INCLUDE NATIONAL O RGANIC COALITION, IFOAM NORTH AMERICA, INTERNATIONAL ORGANIC INSPECTORS ASSOCIATION, ORGANIC FARMING RESEARCH FOUNDATION, LOLA HAMPTON FRANK PINDER CENTER FOR AGROECOLOGY AT FLORIDA A AND M UNIVERSITY, AND NATIONAL YOUNG FARMERS COALITION. OTHER SUBAWARDEES MAY BE ADDED TO ACCOMPLISH THE GOALS OF THE AGREEMENT. THE SUBAWARDS WILL SUPPORT THE PRIME AWARD BY MAKING USE OF PREVIOUS EXPERIENCE OF SUBAWARDEE ORGANIZATIONS TO FACILITATE CONVERSATIONS WITH STAKEHOLDER GROUPS, PRODUCE RESEARCH-BASED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE RESOURCES, UTILIZE PREVIOUS RESEARCH, SHARE RESOURCES AND EDUCATIONAL TOOLS, ASSIST IN OUTREACH AND COMMUNICATION EFFORTS, AND WORK DIRECTLY WITH FARMERS SEEKING ORGANIC CERTIFICATION.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PROVIDE SUPPORT TO TRANSITIONING AND ORGANIC AGRICULTURE PRODUCERS IN THE U.S. MIDWEST (MINNESOTA, WISCONSIN, MICHIGAN, IOWA, ILLINOIS, INDIANA, OHIO, MISSOURI, KENTUCKY, ARKANSAS, TENNESSEE). THE AGREEMENT PROVIDES FOR FARMER-TO-FARMER MENTORING, COMMUNITY BUILDING, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT, AND DATA AND REPORTING. THE RECIPIENT AND PARTNERS WILL PLAN, COORDINATE, AND OVERSEE ACTIVITIES SUCH AS DIRECT FARMER MENTORING, FIELD DAYS, AND EDUCATIONAL EVENTS. THE GOAL OF THE AWARD IS TO HELP AGRICULTURE PRODUCERS OVERCOME BARRIERS TO ORGANIC PRODUCTION AND CERTIFICATION, INCLUDING DURING THE THREE-YEAR TRANSITION PERIOD PRIOR TO ORGANIC CERTIFICATION. RECIPIENTS WILL TRACK PROGRAM PROGRESS THROUGH DATA COLLECTION AND WILL SUBMIT QUARTERLY REPORTS. THIS PROGRAM WILL BENEFIT AGRICULTURE PRODUCERS THROUGH  PROGRAM ACTIVITIES AND BY CREATING TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE MATERIALS (FACTSHEETS, WEBINARS) THAT WILL BE MADE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE THROUGH USDA AND OTHER CHANNELS. THE AWARD WILL RESULT IN SUBAWARDS TO ORGANIC FARMING ORGANIZATIONS, EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTIONS, AND OTHERS WHO WORK WITH FARMING COMMUNITIES. SUBAWARDEES WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR CARRYING OUT ONE OR MORE PRIMARY ACTIVITIES, SUCH AS COORDINATING THE MENTORSHIP PROGRAM IN THEIR STATE OR DEVELOPING  TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE MATERIALS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT, OR PARTNERSHIP, (THE PARTNERSHIP) IS TO ENHANCE AMS’S ABILITY TO ENFORCE THE PSA SO THAT IT CAN ADDRESS THE SIGNIFICANT CHALLENGE OF CONSTRAINED COMPETITION IN THE MEAT AND POULTRY PROCESSING, DISTRIBUTION, AND RETAIL MARKETPLACES.  SPECIFICALLY, TO RESURRECT COMPETITION CONDUCT POLICY IN SUPPORT OF MORE FAIR AND COMPETITIVE MARKET ACCESS TO FOOD WHOLESALE AND RETAIL MARKETS, THE COMPETITION EO DIRECTS USDA TO SUBMIT A REPORT (THE RETAIL REPORT) TO THE CHAIR OF WHITE HOUSE COMPETITION COUNCIL.

SPECIFICALLY, THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WILL ENHANCE AMS’S ABILITY TO EFFECTIVELY ENFORCE THE ACT, AMS IS COMMISSIONING THIS COOPERATIVE PROJECT (THE PROJECT). IT IS PRINCIPALLY ENVISIONED TO HAVE TWO ELEMENTS, WITH SIGNIFICANT INTERACTION BETWEEN THE TWO. THE TWO ELEMENTS ARE AS FOLLOWS: (1) A CONCEPTUAL STUDY OF EXCHANGE TRADING (THE CONCEPTUAL STUDY), AND (2) ANALYSES OF REAL-WORLD IMPACTS OF EXCHANGE TRADING (THE IMPACTS ANALYSIS).
COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT TO DEEPEN KNOWLEDGE OF LEGISLATIVE HISTORY OF THE PSA AND THE RELATIONSHIP OF THE PSA TO OTHER MARKET GOVERNANCE LAWS, I.E. FTCA AND INTERSTATE COMMERCE ACT.
COOPERATIVE AGREEMENTS WITH THE AMERICAN ANTITRUST INSTITUTE
PROVISION OF ADMINISTRATIVE SERVICES AND FACILITATING THE WORK OF THE USDA'S AGRICULTURAL COMPETITION PARTNERSHIP WITH STATE ATTORNEYS GENERAL UNDER A COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT.

THE PURPOSE IS TO PAY THE STATE TO CONDUCT REVIEWS AT GROCERY STORES, SUPERMARKETS, AND CLUB WAREHOUSE STORES ON BEHALF OF USDA. REVIEWS OCCUR AT STORES THROUGHOUT THE STATE TO DETERMINE THE STORE'S COMPLIANCE WITH THE COUNTRY OF ORIGIN REGULATIONS. THE STATE SUBMITS THE REVIEW RESULTS TO THE USDA. USDA ANALYZES THE RESULTS FOR COMPLIANCE AND ENFORCEMENT ACTIONS. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE PUBLIC CONSUMERS BECAUSE THE REVIEWS HELP ENSURE STORES ARE PROVIDING ACCURATE COUNTRY OF ORIGIN INFORMATION FOR CERTAIN FOOD ITEMS (LAMB, GOAT, CHICKEN, FISH, SHELLFISH, FRUITS, VEGETABLES, PEANUTS, PECANS, MACADAMIA NUTS AND GINSENG) TO CONSUMERS AS THEY MAKE THEIR PURCHASING DECISIONS.
TO PROMOTE UNIFORMITY IN SEED TESTING AND TRUTHFUL LABELING, AS REQUIREDUNDER THE FEDERAL SEED ACT AND ITS REGULATIONS, BY PARTNERING WITH AOSATO DEVELOP SEED ANALYST TRAINING WORKSHOPS AND SEMINARS.

THE STATE WILL COLLECT FOOD SAMPLES INTHEIR STATE AND SHIP THE SAMPLES TO THE ASSIGNED LABORATORIES PER THEESTABLISHED SCHEDULE.  THE FOODS, WHICH FOCUS ON THOSE MOST FREQUENTLYCONSUMED BY INFANTS AND CHILDREN, ARE SPECIFIED IN THE CURRENT PDPPROJECT PLAN THAT IS POSTED ON THE PDP WEBSITE.  THE RECEIVING STATELABORATORY WILL PERFORM CHEMICAL ANALYSES ON THE ASSIGNED SAMPLES FORPESTICIDE RESIDUES, INCLUDING PARENT COMPOUNDS AND METABOLITES.  THERESULTS OF THE RESIDUE ANALYSIS WILL BE REVIEWED BY THE STATE QUALITYASSURANCE OFFICER AND SENT TO PDP AS AN ELECTRONIC DATASET.  ALL WORKWILL BE CONDUCTED ACCORDING TO STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES THAT AREAVAILABLE ON THE PDP WEBSITE. THE DELIVERABLE OF THE SAMPLING OPERATIONIS TO PROVIDE THE REQUESTED SAMPLES TO THE LABORATORIES.  THE INTENDEDBENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY, WHO USES THEDATA TO PREPARE DIETARY RISK ASSESSMENTS FOR PESTICIDES; THE FOOD ANDDRUG ADMINISTRATION WHO USES THE ROUTINE MONITORING DATA FROM PDP TOINFORM THEIR REGULATORY ENFORCEMENT OF ESTABLISHED LIMITS OF PESTICIDERESIDUES IN FOOD; THE USDA FOREIGN AGRICULTURAL SERVICE WHO MAY USE THEDATA IN TRADE NEGOTIATIONS; AND AMERICAN CONSUMERS WHO USE THE DATA TOHELP ENSURE THEIR CONFIDENCE IN THE FOOD THEY PURCHASE FOR THEIRFAMILIES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO PLAN AND PILOT AN ORGANIC AGRICULTURECOURSE FOR UNIVERSITY STUDENTS THAT WILL PREPARE THEM FOR IMMEDIATEEMPLOYMENT WITH AN ORGANIC CERTIFIER UPON GRADUATION. ACTIVITIES WILLINCLUDE CREATING NEW COURSE CONTENT, TEACHING THE COURSE INCOLLABORATION WITH ORGANIC INDUSTRY REPRESENTATIVES, REVISING COURSECONTENT BASED ON THE PILOT YEAR, AND TRAINING STUDENTS TO CREATERESOURCES FOR THEIR LOCAL ORGANIC FARMING COMMUNITY. THE RECIPIENT OFTHIS AWARD WILL DEVELOP A REPORT, INCLUDING NEWLY DEVELOPED COURSECONTENT, THAT WILL EXPLAIN HOW TO IMPLEMENT A UNIVERSITY PROGRAM THATPREPARES STUDENTS FOR EMPLOYMENT IN THE ORGANIC AGRICULTURE SECTOR. THISREPORT AND ASSOCIATED RESOURCES WILL BE MADE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE SO THATOTHER EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTIONS ACROSS THE UNITED STATES MAY DEVELOPSIMILAR PROGRAMS. IN ADDITION TO THE RECIPIENT, STUDENTS, ORGANICFARMERS IN THE LOCAL PROJECT AREA, AND OTHER INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHEREDUCATION WILL BENEFIT. THE INTENT OF THE PROJECT IS TO SUPPORTWORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT FOR THE ORGANIC INDUSTRY. THIS AWARD MAY RESULT INSUBAWARDS TO ORGANIC INDUSTRY PARTNERS WHO WILL CONTRIBUTE THEIREXPERTISE TO COURSE DEVELOPMENT.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO CREATE RESOURCES AND TRAINING THATWILL SUPPORT A MORE DIVERSE, EQUITABLE, AND INCLUSIVE ORGANICPROFESSIONALS COMMUNITY. ORGANIC PROFESSIONALS INCLUDES ORGANIZATIONSAND INDIVIDUALS WHO OVERSEE OR PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE RELATED TOORGANIC AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION. THE RECIPIENT WILL HOST A PUBLICLYAVAILABLE WORKSHOP AND TRAINING SERIES AND WILL SUPPORT FACILITATEDLEARNING SESSIONS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND BARRIERS TO DIVERSITY, EQUITY,AND INCLUSION IN THE ORGANIC AGRICULTURE SECTOR. THE RECIPIENT WILLPROVIDE FACTSHEETS, FINAL REPORTS, AND TRAINING ASSETS TO THE AWARDINGAGENCY. THESE DELIVERABLES WILL BE MADE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE. THE WORKPERFORMED UNDER THIS AGREEMENT WILL BENEFIT THE ORGANIC AGRICULTURESECTOR, INCLUDING CERTIFIERS, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PROVIDERS, ANDFARMERS, INCLUDING THOSE FROM HISTORICALLY UNDERSERVED POPULATIONS. THISAWARD WILL RESULT IN SUBAWARDS TO CAMBIUM COLLECTIVE AND UP WITHCOMMUNITY. THESE GROUPS WILL SUPPORT THE PRIME AWARD BY FACILITATINGLEARNING SESSIONS AND TRAINING EVENTS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO CONDUCT THE ANNUAL PEER REVIEW OF THE NATIONAL ORGANIC PROGRAM, PROVIDE ISO TRAINING TO AUDITORS AND ACCREDITATION MANAGERS, AND PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE ON DEVELOPING THE NOP'S ACCREDITATION POLICIES AND PROCEDURES. THE RECIPIENT WILL CONDUCT THE PEER REVIEW, PROVIDE TRAINING, AND PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO THE NOP. THE RECIPIENT WILL WRITE A FINAL REPORT BASED ON THE PEER REVIEW RESULTS WHICH THE NATIONAL ORGANIC PROGRAM WILL RESPOND TO AND MAKE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE. THE RECIPIENT WILL PROVIDE CERTIFICATES OF COMPLETION FOR THE ISO TRAINING THEY CONDUCT, AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO THE ACCREDITATION DIVISION. THIS WORK WILL BENEFIT THE NATIONAL ORGANIC PROGRAM BY MAINTAINING COMPLIANCE WITH THE USDA ORGANIC REGULATIONS AND THE ENTIRE ORGANIC AGRICULTURE COMMUNITY. THE AWARD WILL NOT RESULT IN SUBAWARDS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO CREATE EDUCATIONAL RESOURCES FORORGANIC INSPECTORS WHICH WILL IMPROVE OVERSIGHT CAPACITY AND PROTECT THEINTEGRITY OF ORGANIC AGRICULTURE IN THE UNITED STATES. THE RECIPIENTWILL DEVELOP ONLINE TRAINING CURRICULUM TO TEACH INSPECTION SKILLS ATORGANIC HANDLING AND PROCESSING OPERATIONS. THE AWARD WILL RESULT IN AFREE, PUBLICLY AVAILABLE INSPECTION HANDLING COURSE IN THE ORGANICINTEGRITY LEARNING CENTER AND WILL BENEFIT ORGANIC INSPECTORS AND OTHERCERTIFICATION PROFESSIONALS. THE AWARD WILL NOT RESULT IN SUBAWARDS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO PROVIDE RESEARCH ACTIVITIES TO EVALUATESUBSTANCES FOR USE IN ORGANIC AGRICULTURE PRODUCTION. THE RECIPIENT WILLCONDUCT RESEARCH AND AUTHOR UP TO 15 TECHNICAL REPORTS ON SUBSTANCESEITHER PRESENT OR PETITIONED FOR INCLUSION ON THE NATIONAL LIST OFALLOWED AND PROHIBITED SUBSTANCES, WHICH EXPLAINS WHAT SUBSTANCES CAN BEUSED IN ORGANIC AGRICULTURE PRODUCTION. THIS WORK WILL INFORM THENATIONAL ORGANIC STANDARDS BOARD, A FEDERAL ADVISORY BOARD, IN ITSREVIEW OF SUBSTANCES. AFTER THE REPORTS HAVE BEEN DEEMED SUFFICIENT,THEY WILL BE PUBLISHED FOR PUBLIC VIEWING ON THE AGRICULTURAL MARKETINGSERVICE NATIONAL ORGANIC PROGRAM WEBSITE AND WILL BE REFERENCED IN THEWORK COMPLETED BY THE BOARD. THIS WORK WILL BENEFIT THE ENTIRE ORGANICAGRICULTURE COMMUNITY BY INFORMING FAIR REGULATIONS THAT ARE CONSISTENTWITH PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS AND CURRENT SCIENTIFIC KNOWLEDGE. THE AWARDWILL NOT RESULT IN SUBAWARDS.
THE PURPOSE IS TO PROVIDE SCIENTISTS AAAS FELLOWSHIPS ALLOWING THEM TOLEVERAGE THEIR SCIENTIFIC EXPERTISE WHILE ALSO WORKING IN POLICY,JOURNALISM, AND OTHER RELATED FIELDS.

THE PURPOSE IS TO PAY THE STATE TO CONDUCT REVIEWS AT GROCERY STORES,SUPERMARKETS, AND CLUB WAREHOUSE STORES ON BEHALF OF USDA. REVIEWS OCCURAT STORES THROUGHOUT THE STATE TO DETERMINE THE STORE'S COMPLIANCE WITHTHE COUNTRY OF ORIGIN REGULATIONS. THE STATE SUBMITS THE REVIEW RESULTSTO THE USDA. USDA ANALYZES THE RESULTS FOR COMPLIANCE AND ENFORCEMENTACTIONS. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES ARE PUBLIC CONSUMERS BECAUSE THEREVIEWS HELP ENSURE STORES ARE PROVIDING ACCURATE COUNTRY OF ORIGININFORMATION FOR CERTAIN FOOD ITEMS (LAMB, GOAT, CHICKEN, FISH,SHELLFISH, FRUITS, VEGETABLES, PEANUTS, PECANS, MACADAMIA NUTS ANDGINSENG) TO CONSUMERS AS THEY MAKE THEIR PURCHASING DECISIONS.
